item.title: AS3 creating an array of items
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

I actually need to re-write this flash game. A lot of objects are added to stage that don’t need to be, there’s a bunch of extra symbols (movie clips, graphics, buttons) and way to much code in the actual flash file and not the as3 files.

I will think it is a good thing that he learns to use an engine before making it, so he know what to make.

item.title: AS3 creating an array of items
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Lin:

You should learn how to make game engines from scratch. You’ll learn the many ways to test for collisions, including bounding box, pixel-based, and ray tracing collisions.

I understand that. I’m barley writing my first game. Well, my first real game. The others I did were half assed pieces of shit. Literal. There were so many bugs, and such.
I’m really trying with this one.

Bowser jr:

True if that is his purpose. I’m under the impression that he is interested in an easy way of doing this without clogging the CPU. I will think it is a good thing that he learns to use an engine before making it, so he know what to make.

In time I will make one. In time.

Read full topic

item.title: AS3 creating an array of items
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:13, topic:516259”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=634518.msg4283685#msg4283685 date=1366064176]

And to answer your earlier question, Bowser. I’m using them for colliders. Because for some stupid reason when I draw a line it doesn’t work properly for my collider.

Then why didn’t you say you wanted what? That is quite easy. Do some math and you are done.

It’s object on object collision. the issue is that when I hit the background object using hitTestObject() [a flash function] my player can’t move expect for jumping until I’m above the map I drew out. So I was using hitTestPoint() to check if any item in my array of points would hit my background object.
[/quote]
Don’t use hitTestObject, it is terrible. The easiest for you would be to use Box2D, make everything much easier if you aren’t capable of making your own simple engine.[/quote]
I’ll look into it tomorrow when I get to school, all my work is there

Read full topic
item.source: AS3 creating an array of items

item.title: AS3 creating an array of items
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:12, topic:516259”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=634518.msg4283480#msg4283480 date=1366042731]

And to answer your earlier question, Bowser. I’m using them for colliders. Because for some stupid reason when I draw a line it doesn’t work properly for my collider.

Then why didn’t you say you wanted what? That is quite easy. Do some math and you are done.
[/quote]
It’s object on object collision. the issue is that when I hit the background object using hitTestObject() [a flash function] my player can’t move expect for jumping until I’m above the map I drew out. So I was using hitTestPoint() to check if any item in my array of points would hit my background object.[/quote]
Don’t use hitTestObject, it is terrible. The easiest for you would be to use Box2D, make everything much easier if you aren’t capable of making your own simple engine.

Read full topic
item.source: AS3 creating an array of items

item.title: AS3 creating an array of items
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:10, topic:516259”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=634518.msg4283465#msg4283465 date=1366039249]
And to answer your earlier question, Bowser. I’m using them for colliders. Because for some stupid reason when I draw a line it doesn’t work properly for my collider.

[/quote]
Then why didn’t you say you wanted what? That is quite easy. Do some math and you are done.[/quote]
It’s object on object collision. the issue is that when I hit the background object using hitTestObject() [a flash function] my player can’t move expect for jumping until I’m above the map I drew out. So I was using hitTestPoint() to check if any item in my array of points would hit my background object.

Read full topic

item.title: AS3 creating an array of items
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

en.m.wikipedia.org

Bresenham's line algorithm

Bresenham's line algorithm is an algorithm that determines the points of an n-dimensional raster that should be selected in order to form a close approximation to a straight line between two points. It is commonly used to draw line primitives in a bitmap image (e.g. on a computer screen), as it uses only integer addition, subtraction and bit shifting, all of which are very cheap operations in standard computer architectures. It is an incremental error algorithm. It is one of the earliest algorith...

Read full topic
item.source: AS3 creating an array of items

item.title: AS3 creating an array of items
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:6, topic:516259”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=634518.msg4283457#msg4283457 date=1366037786]

What are you trying to do?

Fill an array with all possible points between -27, 0 (X, Y) and 25, 0 (X, Y).

And it seems like you have done it. Congratulation. You now have a useless list of points.

Congratulations, you are a moron. I’m using it for something.
I haven’t made all points. It goes to the second decimal place. So there’s hundreds of points I missed.
[/quote]
You know that you cannot make a complete list, as there is infinite points between any two points.
But to answer you, have you tried
for(var itm4 = -25.00; itm4 <= 27.00;itm4+= 0.01)

What are you going to do with those point, it seems like you are doing something extremely inefficient.[/quote]
I know I cannot make ALL possible points, but Flash uses to the second decimal place for X and Y.
And no, I didn’t try that and I believe it worked.

Read full topic

item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

What are you trying to do?

Fill an array with all possible points between -27, 0 (X, Y) and 25, 0 (X, Y).

And it seems like you have done it. Congratulation. You now have a useless list of points.
[/quote]
Congratulations, you are a moron. I’m using it for something.
I haven’t made all points. It goes to the second decimal place. So there’s hundreds of points I missed.[/quote]
You know that you cannot make a complete list, as there is infinite points between any two points.
But to answer you, have you tried
for(var itm4 = -25.00; itm4 <= 27.00;itm4+= 0.01)

What are you going to do with those point, it seems like you are doing something extremely inefficient.

Read full topic

item.source: AS3 creating an array of items

item.title: AS3 creating an array of items
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

So I’m making an array of Points in AS3 as lines don’t want to work right for what I’m doing (I have no damn reason why), but the points aren’t as accurate as I need.
Right now the points in the array look like this:
Point(-27, 0);
Point(-26, 0);
and so on to (25, 0);
Now if you know anything about lines, there’s lots of gaps in this.
I need it to go to the second decimal place so it looks a bit more like:
Point(-27.00, 0);
Point(-26.99, 0);
and so on to (25.00, 0);
I tried using Number (That’s a key word in flash :P), which could go to the second decimal place.

No, I’m not stupid enough to manually (what I mean is actually typing Point(-27, 0); ) write all 53 items in the array(currently) or all 530 (I think).
I use a for loop:

var downPoint:Array = new Array(); for(var itm4 = -25.00; itm4 <= 27.00;itm4++){ var s:Point = new Point(itm4, 0); downPoint.push(s); }

Read full topic
item.source: AS3 creating an array of items
